title: sajid javid huddersfield asian grooming tweet
story: A politician who doesn’t retract his comments just because they upset the kind of people who make a career out of being upset.That politician is Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary — though perhaps we should refer to him as the Home Truth Secretary because he has been delivering a fair few of those recently.This week, Javid was offered an opportunity to backtrack on something he said a few months ago.And amazingly — given we live in an era of spineless politics in which MPs are forever repenting for something they said — he turned down the opportunity.Javid’s speech-crime was to tweet about Muslim grooming gangs.In October, he tweeted a heartfelt comment about the Huddersfield grooming gang —  men who were found guilty of  offences against  girls.They pursued a “campaign of rape and abuse” against their vulnerable victims, said the judge at Leeds Crown Court.Javid described their predatory behaviour — including against a teenage girl who had the mental age of a seven-year-old — as “vile and wicked”.In his tweet commenting on the case — he referred to the  men as “sick Asian paedophiles”.Cue instant meltdown in PC circles.For Javid to use the A-word — “Asian” — was nasty and offensive, they spluttered.Like a modern-day Inquisition, the permanently outraged Twitterati denounced Javid for “racialising” the crimes in Huddersfield.Labour MP David Lammy said Javid had increased “the risk of violence and abuse against minorities”.Labour’s Diane Abbott slammed him for “attributing these crimes to one ethnic group”.But here is the thing —we are talking about the Huddersfield crimes, as Javid was, it is absolutely right to “attribute these crimes to one ethnic group”.As the BBC reported at the time, the  Huddersfield groomers were “all British Asians, mainly of Pakistani heritage”.Javid, who is also of Pakistani heritage, was telling the truth. Every word of his tweet was correct — these men are sick, they are paedophiles and they are Asian.When politicians are condemned for telling the truth, for stating plain-as-day facts, you know we live in scarily censorious times.So, this week, Javid was right to turn down an invitation to “rethink” his October tweet.He was on the Today programme on Radio . A guest presenter — the British-Pakistani novelist Kamila Shamsie — asked himhe thought his tweet might have fuelled hate crimes. Coolly, and with rare principle, Javid said that of course politicians must be “careful with their language”.Butyou look at recent high-profile cases of gang-based sexual exploitation, “there is a high proportion of men that have Pakistani heritage”, he said.He’s right.Rotherham, Oxford, Rochdale, Derby, Telford, Newcastle, Huddersfield . . . across England there have been awful grooming-gang cases, where the perpetrators have largely been Muslim men and the victims white working-class girls.We must be free to talk about this. To analyse it. To ask how such a terrible situation came about where vulnerable, mostly white girls are preyed upon by wicked, mainly Muslim men.But we are not free to talk about it. Anybody who raises the issue of Muslim grooming gangs risks being branded as foul, a racist, a troublemaker whose words will fuel hate crimes.Indeed, Javid has been subjected to genuine racist abuse for speaking out on the issue.Vile, hard-left tweeters have denounced him as an “Uncle Tom” and a “coconut”.Such disgusting racist insults reveal where the real prejudice lies in this debate — not in Javid’s concerned comments, but in the PC outrage that effectively says to him: “Shut up, Coconut.” Javid was not being prejudiced but many of the supposed progressives raging against him have been.It is all a sign of the times. From Conservatives such as Javid, to Labour MP Sarah Champion and radical feminists such as Julie Bindel, anyone who expresses concern about Pakistani-heritage grooming gangs can expect to be bombarded with abuse.But a nation that cannot discuss its communal tensions is a nation that is in very serious trouble.That signicant numbers of Muslim men are abusing signicant numbers of white working-class girls suggests “multicultural Britain” is a fractured, sometimes ugly place — and we must be at liberty to talk about this.Shushing debate about Muslim grooming gangs is insulting not only to the victims of those gangs, but to Britain’s Muslim community, too.It suggests they are too fragile, too weak, to cope with honest debate about problems and crimes within their communities.So let us be thankful for Sajid Javid — a politician who is willing to look modern Britain in the face and ask it some dficult but essential questions.This is a Tory to watch.Their latest wheeze is to force restaurants and supermarkets to impose “calorie caps” on their dishes.Public Health England is thinking about stopping supermarkets from selling sarnies that have more than  calories and capping restaurant meals at  calories. This would effectively mean using the power of the state to force us slovenly, greedy plebs to go on diets.It’s so paternalistic.Here’s a radical idea – bugger off and let people eat whatever they want.Our lunchtime triple-decker sandwich and occasional restaurant blowout are none of your business.TALK about a self-fulfilling prophecy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: When Texan Rakhi Desai received the soft toy for Christmas, she didn’t think anything was unusual about it.It was only two weeks later than she discovered it contained someone’s ashes, ABC reported.The Houston-based woman has now set off on a mission to reunite the bear with his family.A pal had picked up the toy at an estate sale.It has a persons name, a small heart stitching, and Neptune Society written on its foot.This turned out to be the name of a crematorium.What Desai had taken for small pebbles inside the bear turned out to be someone’s ashes.She said: It seems to be that this bear is very special to somebody and belongs in somebodys family.Her efforts so far to locate the family have failed, but she still holds out hope.She said: Miracles happen every day… So,theres a positive end to this story, that would be great.

title: highs lows and dance moves of british politics 2018 wooding
story: Here, Sunday Political Editor David Wooding takes a light-hearted look at the year in politics for his annual awards, The Wooders.Chancellor Philip “Spreadsheet” Hammond launched a wave of blue-on-blue insults at Cabinet ­colleagues — especially Brexiteers — when he gleefully talked of “flushing out extremists”.He branded Boris Johnson a “bogeyman” and cuttingly said of Welfare ­Secretary Esther McVey: “The only thing she knows how to do well is a blow dry.”But while both of them have since left the Cabinet, Big Phil is still in place.Donald Trump arrived late for his ­meeting with the Queen during his ­controversial summer visit to Britain.The -year-old monarch was seen ­looking at her watch after being kept standing outside Windsor Castle for  minutes.But the US ­President brashly insisted he was early and, you’ve guessed it, his late arrival was “fake news”.Goes to the protester with the placard: “Super- callous, fragile ego, Trump, you are atrocious.”Ex-PM David Cameron told pals he fancied a political comeback as he is “bored s**tless”. We’re not surprised he’s “s**tless” — he left his colleagues up to their knees in the stuff.Boris Johnson warned that ­trying to sell the PM’s Brexit blueprint to voters was “like ­trying to polish a turd”. Six months on, Theresa May is still buffing away and her tin of Election Pledge is nearly empty.Mrs May was written off  months ago after that disastrous party conference speech — but a year on, she shimmied on stage to Abba’s Dancing Queen.Since then, she’s survived a no-confidence vote forced by Tory rebels and attempts to sink her loathed Brexit plan. Who’d bet against her being in No this time next year Brexiteer-in-chief Jacob Rees-Mogg and his supporters were ­likened to Dad’s Army after their attempted leadership coup flopped. But the posh Tory brushed off the jibe, ­saying: “I’ve always admired Captain Mainwaring.”On a visit to Beijing, Foreign ­Secretary Jeremy Hunt tried telling his opposite number that his we is Chinese — but called her “Japanese”. The two countries are bitter rivals and neither his hosts nor his ­missus were amused.Labour’s Emily Thornberry described the Government as “the equivalent of Reservoir Dogs remade by the Chuckle Brothers”.EU Commission chief Jean-Claude “Drunker” Juncker just about struggled to stay on his feet at summits this year.He ruffled a woman official’s hair and was ­challenged by Mrs May when he dubbed her “nebulous”.But he insisted they ended up kissing. It’s hard to know how he’d remember after his famous lunches.Jeremy Corbyn infuriated MPs — and kept lip-readers busy — when he mouthed “stupid woman” at the PM at Commons ­question time.The ­Labour leader, who says he wants a “kinder, gentler” politics, insisted he didn’t, but lip-readers said he did. Stupid boy.Angry female MPs said “knickers” to Tory MP Christopher Chope after he single-handedly blocked moves to make taking pictures up skirts a criminal offence — and hung a string of undies outside his ­Commons office.Two ­Russian hitmen wanted for the Salisbury nerve agent attack claimed they were sightseers ­visiting the city’s cathedral and insisted they had left early to escape a dusting of snow. Pull the other one, Vlad.Sir Nick Clegg once said he found the “messianic Calornian new-worldy touchy-feely culture of ­Facebook a little grating”.Now he’s happy to take a £million-a-year job as its global affairs boss, and it’s smiley emojis all the way to the bank.Labour deputy leader Tom Watson shed an incredible st after giving up sugar, eating healthier food and exercising.Trim Tom should have a word with his boss about plans to gorge on ­taxpayers’ money.Forgetful Sir Vince Cable was so busy plotting to halt Brexit, he missed a key Commons vote on it, allowing the Customs Bill to scrape through by just three votes.The Lib Dem leader later announced that he will stand down next year. Some of his ten MPs had begun to think he’d already left.Speaker John Bercow was accused of bullying staff, ­muttering “stupid woman” at Commons leader Andrea Leadsom and displaying a “B*****ks To Brexit” car sticker, despite impartiality rules. Yet he’s still in the chair after vowing to “keep buggering on”.Dominic Raab admitted he “hadn’t quite understood” the importance of our £billion-a-year trade with France — four months after becoming Brexit Secretary and a week before he resigned.Tracey Crouch made an unusual stand by resigning over a matter of principle — forcing the Chancellor into a Budget U-turn and saving lives in the process.She quit as Sports Minister over delays to a crackdown on high-stakes betting machines which she blames for suicides among debt-ridden gamblers. Her stand forced the Government to act within days.After Tory Brexiteer John Hayes was knighted — seen as a ploy to buy his ­support for the PM’s hated Brexit plan — colleague Mark Francois urged him to get a coat of arms containing “an utter cock ­rampant on one side and a big chicken on the other”.New Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright revealed he likes to unwind by playing with his “very large” Lego set. Maybe he should be in charge of housing instead.Wannabe PM Boris Johnson milked his exit as Foreign Secretary by inviting a photographer to snap him writing his resignation letter. One MP branded him “a poundshop Churchill impressionist”.It’s not just the wheels of Government that need oiling, but the PM’s joints, judging by her dancing during an ­African trip. Looks like the Maybot needs to add a pair of dancing shoes to her kitten heel collection this year.Pepper the robot was questioned by a  of MPs about the impact of articial intelligence. It was hailed as a Commons first, although anyone who’s seen Theresa May or Sajid Javid in action may beg to dfer.Labour bruiser John Prescott became a victim of ­mistaken identity when his picture appeared in The Times, captioned as Clint Eastwood. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: booze free parliament commons curb drinking culture
story: Strict new controls on drinking within the Westminster estate will be rolled out after agreement among senior MPs.The powerful House of Commons Commission will implement “alcohol-free” areas which should be “encouraged and expanded”.There will also be a marked rise in the range of non-alcoholic drinks and lower strength beers for sale.The restrictions follow Commons Speaker John Bercow allegedly demanding a prohibition-style drink ban during the day.The move comes just over a year since the so-called Pestminster scandal that led to the resignation of Defence Secretary Michael Fallon. He stood accused of “lunging” at a female journalist and kissing her on the lips after a boozy lunch.It also follows the Dame Laura Cox report into bullying and harassment culture on the Parliamentary estate.Abuse of staff may have been made worse by the “ready access” to alcohol across bars and restaurants on the premises.In her report, Dame Laura said: “The steps taken so far to restrict access to alcohol during working hours may need to be revisited.”Changes to the availability of alcohol will also include adverts promoting alcohol in bars will be banned.MPs and staff will also be contacted asking them to “refrain” from drinking in their offices after bars on the estate have shut.Labour MP Jess Phillips last night said: “This is a step in the right direction. Parliament is a place of work and not a cruise ship.“However, unless the culture of power and political friendships mattering more than anything, these measures will be window dressing.”A spokesperson for the House of Commons Commission: “The House of Commons Commission has agreed a number of actions to promote responsible alcohol consumption.Our total trade with the zone last year was worth £billion.International Trade Secretary Dr Fox said: “The Scotch whisky industry supports more than , UK jobs.”“These include increasing the range of non-alcoholic drinks and lower strength beers available, training and supporting staff to refuse to serve customers when necessary, expanding and encouraging alcohol-free areas, discouraging Members and staff from drinking in offices after bars are shut, and not running promotional advertisements.“Bullying and harassment have no place in the House of Commons. We recognise the impact of bullying and harassment described in the Dame Laura Cox report and will continue to work closely with staff, unions and Workplace Equality Networks to address these issues.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: liam fox claims brexit has 50 chance of being scrapped if mps vote down theresa mays deal
story: Dr Fox, a pro-Leave minister, said Brexit will only be “ per cent certain”the House of Commons backs Mrs May’s deal in a crunch vote next month.He told the Sunday Times it would be “incendiary”fellow MPs fail to pass the Prime Minister’s Withdrawal Agreement.The International Trade Secretary, , added it was a “matter of honour” for them to support her.Referring to the EU referendum, he said: “Parliament cannot now, with any honour, renege on that result.”He added: “Were they to do so, I think you would shatter the bond of trust between the electorate and Parliament.“And I think that would put us into unprecedented territory with unknowable consequences.”Dr Fox said he “would not give it much more than -” for the UK to leave the EUMrs May’s deal is rejected.Campaigners for a second EU referendum seized on the International Trade Secretarys comments, saying that polls suggested that fewer than  per cent of Brits now want to leave the EU.Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran, a leading supporter of the Best for Britain campaign for a referendum, said: Brexit not happening isnt - as Liam Fox says. Its actually -.Thats the way the public now feels about us stopping this badly-led disaster and strengthening ourselves within the EU.The only thing that is shattering the bond of trust between electorate and Parliament is the refusal of ministers like Liam Fox to trust people with the final say on Brexit.

Cops believe Xing Lei Li, , may have been killed and thrown overboard in a suitcase while on ­holiday with Irish hubby Daniel Belling and their two young children.The Chinese national hasn’t been seen since February ,  — the day after the family boarded a ten-day MSC ­Magnica cruise of the Mediterranean.Murder suspect Belling claims she walked off the ship in the Greek port of Katakolon after a row — despite the cruise operators insisting its electronic systems would have picked this up.His lawyer has now unearthed ­bombshell new ­evidence showing Xing’s credit card was used to pay a toll on Dublin’s M after she disappeared.And it’s emerged the locks on their Dublin house were changed — while Belling was sitting in an Italian prison as cops probed the baffling case.Lawyer Luigi Conti yesterday blasted officers for failing to consider that Xing might still be alive as he revealed they had discovered she had “a lover”.He said: “On her mobile phone there were messages, explicit sexual messages, showing there was an extra conjugal relationship. The mobile number sending the messages was an Irish number.“I just find it astonishing, that from the right beginning, they only believed her, to be dead. They never went ­looking for her.”Computer programmer Belling was lted as he tried to fly home from Rome’s Ciampino Airport with their kids after the cruise on February , .He was released last April and is now living back in Clarehall, Dublin, with his children and his Chinese mother-in-law while the probe continues in Italy.She has defended him as “a very good person”, telling an Italian TV show: “I don’t think he could hurt my daughter.”Solicitor Conti said the case is due to go to trial in March and claims ­evidence obtained by Belling’s nephew should be enough to exonerate him.He told the Irish Sun: “An invoice was sent to us in the post by Daniel’s nephew. It showed her credit card had been used to pay the motorway close to Dublin after Daniel was arrested.”Conti said the M toll was paid on March , . He continued: “While Mr Belling was in prison, I was given back his house keys. Daniel’s nephew went to the family home and then called me.“As he found out that he could not open the house with those keys, I advised him to call the police and check with them,there had been any kind of measures.Nothing had been carried out or was done.“Together with the police, Daniel’s nephew opened the door. The house was in order. No one had broken in.“It was clear, that someone entered the house and changed the locks. The we had a set of keys. According to her husband, she was the only one to have copy of the keys. story: NewsEarl of real-le Downton Abbey stands for lelong seat in Parliament - and you dont get a voteGeorge Reginald Oliver Molyneux Herbert, the th Earl of Carnarvon, is one of  aristocrats who want to make your laws for up to £ a day in the worlds most elitist electionShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsGeorge Herbert, the th Earl of Carnarvon, lives at Highclere Castle - now famous as TVs Downton Abbey "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory Earl who owns the real-le Downton Abbey is standing for a lelong seat in Parliament - and the British public wont even get a vote. George Reginald Oliver Molyneux Herbert is one of  aristocrats competing in a hereditary peer by-election in the House of Lords. Only hereditary peers can stand in the bizarre poll, a hangover from attempts to reform the Lords, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The winner will be able to shape laws and claim pound a day until they die or retire - a situation previously branded a mockery of our democracy. The -year-old th Earl of Carnarvon lives with his countess we in Highclere Castle on a ,-acre estate in Hampshire. The lavish house with a state dining room, library and smoking room was used as the home of the Crawley family in ITVs fictional period drama.   His ancestor the rd Earl remodelled the sprawling manor, whose origins date to AD, in the s into the stately home that is now famous around the world. And the th Earl practiced digging in its grounds before joining forces with Howard Carter to discover the tomb of Tutankhamun in Egypt. Tours of the estate cost pound a head while a Valentines Day tour with afternoon tea costs pound for a couple. In a manesto to fellow peers, the th Earl said owning his home has given him experience of small business, farming, tourism and countryside heritage matters that would help him in the House of Lords.  He added the residences renown gives him an international outlook to the world through Highcleres presence online. He also wrote he could bring experience from investing and working in software and technology, and promised to take part in committees and debates. The election is a hangover from Tony Blairs bid to modernise the House of Lords. Hereditary peers were mostly cast out in  but  remained as a compromise. That means when one dies or retires, remaining hereditary peers get first refusal on the seat, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The latest election is being held to replace Tory Lord Skelmersdale, an Old Etonian who sat in the Lords for  years before his death in October.  Ten of the  candidates are Conservatives, five are independent crossbenchers and one, Lord Cadman, has not declared a party affiliation. Rival candidates include -year-old Lord Biddulph, whose entire manesto is the words always happy to serve, and Viscount Mountgarret, whose family own , acres of land devoted to game hunting in North Yorkshire. Other candidates include retired Navy commander the Earl of Effingham and state secondary school teacher Lord Hampton. Peers will be invited to cast their ballot in the opulent Queens robing room in the House of Lords on January . They can also vote by post. The by-election, expected to cost just over pound, to run, is the fourth of its kind since the start of . Darren Hughes, Chief Executive of the Electoral Reform Society, said earlier this year hereditary peer by-elections are an undemocratic farce and make mockery of our democracy.

story: NewsSajid Javid jets home from luxury family holiday to face migrant boats crisisThe plight of desperate migrants in the English Channel has exploded into a political row as a Tory MP attacked the Home Secretarys "half-hearted Dads Army" tacticsShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsSajid Javid declared a major incident but at first he stayed abroad "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHome Secretary Sajid Javid was skulking back to Britain today amid mounting criticism of his “Dads Army” handling of migrants in the Channel. The top Tory was forced to cut short his Christmas holiday in South Africa after  desperate people including children were intercepted trying to cross the Strait of Dover since Christmas Day. On Friday Mr Javid declared the situation a major incident and appointed a Gold Commander amid warnings it was a matter of time until a mass death. But he reportedly only decided yesterday to abandon a holiday with his family in a lodge that costs pound-per-person-per-night,you share a room. The Sunday Times reported he stayed in Dulini Lodge in the Kruger National Park, a .million-acre wilderness home to lions, leopards, rhinos and elephants. Guests at the riverside lodge are promised a symphony of birdsong in private plunge pools, three-hour safari drives and sundown cocktails overlooking the park. It is believed Mr Javid had been away for just four days when he took the decision to cut short his break - and had not yet had the chance to go on safari.  A source close to the Home Secretary would not confirm where he had stayed but insisted he had not been on safari. Mr Javids actions prompted demands for him to get a grip as the issue exploded into a political row. Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson added to the pressure on his Cabinet colleague, saying the armed forces were ready to help. We have not had any requests as yet butthe Home Office is in need of armed forces support then our Navy, Air Force and Army stand ready to assist,” he told the Sunday . Some pundits branded Mr Williamsons intervention a proxy battle for the Tory leadership after Theresa May steps down before the next election in . And critics have attacked the scale of the response to  migrants crossing the Channel - compared to the , children in the UK in temporary accommodation over Christmas. Labour MP Karen Lee added: Given the numbers of Grenfell survivors left homeless under hiswatch, many still not permanently rehoused, the news that Sajid Javid is charging home to tackle the migrant crisis is worrying. These people are vulnerable refugees.  Six men were apprehended by Border Force officials at .am today on a beach in Kingsdown, Kent - bringing the estimated number of people detained trying to cross the Channel to  since Christmas Day. The six men, all Iranian nationals, have been given a medical assessment and have been transferred to immigration officials for processing. Mr Javid claimed he was keeping the number of Border Force vessels in the Channel under close review, but claimed there was no one easy answer. Home Office officials fear upping the number of cutters in the Channel - currently there is just one - could incentivise people smugglers to send more people on the dangerous journey. Conservative MP Rehman Chishti, who sits on the Commons Home Affairs Select Committee, blasted a lack of leadership to get a grip on this issue. Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Tory MP for Dover and Deal Charlie Elphicke called for all five of the Border Forces Cutters to be deployed in the Channel as a powerful deterrent. Rejecting Mr Javids suggestion that increasing patrols would encourage more people to attempt the crossing, Mr Elphicke - who met Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes in Dover yesterday - said: You dont deter burglars by leaving your front door open.  He added: This cannot be done on the cheap with the half-hearted Dads Army-type set-up suggested by the Home Office in the past.” Writing in the Sunday Mirror, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott blasted Mr Javid for failing to get a grip on criminal people smugglers. She said: He has still to explain exactly how the Government plans to handle these mass criminal operations in British waters. The Home Offices flawed strategy has been to focus on deterring refugees, thinking that the issues in the Mediterranean would never reach our shores. While the Tories wax lyrical about control of our borders and being tough on security, they cannot seem to get a grip on criminal smugglers operating on a few hundred miles of coastline, in one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world.

story: NewsTory Jeremy Hunt says Brexit Britain should be like low tax haven SingaporeSingapore has a corporation tax rate of % and campaigners warn "nothing would help the elite out more"ShareCommentsByAndrew Woodcock:,  DEC NewsForeign Secretary Jeremy Hunt pictured second left with Theresa May "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailForeign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has suggested the UK should follow the example of low-tax Singapore as it forges a new position in the world after Brexit. In what will be seen as a bid to burnish his credentials with Tory Brexiteers, Mr Hunt hailed the south-east Asian city state for plugging into the international economic grid on gaining its independence in . He also dismissed alternatives to Theresa Mays EU Withdrawal Agreement, denouncing the option of a second referendum as a dereliction of duty and warning that a no-deal Brexit could leave us poorer. Singapore has long been touted as a model for the UK after EU withdrawal by fervent Brexiteers such as former minister Owen Paterson, who last year wrote that Britain should adopt its low-tax, low-spend, low-regulation policies .  Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Mr Hunt said Singapore had transformed itself from a tiny territory devoid of natural resources into the worlds eighth richest country. He added: While the circumstances of Britains departure from the EU are dferent, there could be few better instructions for us as we make our post-Brexit future. The Foreign Secretary, who backed Remain in , has emerged as a potential successor to Mrs May after shting his position to back Brexit. While acknowledging that the Prime Ministers Withdrawal Agreement is not perfect, he urged fellow MPs to back it in next months crunch vote. All other options are fraught with danger and would create more problems than they solve, he warned.  A second referendum would ide the country again right at the moment when people need to come together, said Mr Hunt. And warning against the no-deal option favoured by some Leave-backing MPs, he said: No-one should be encouraging a move that could leave us poorer at the same time as gladdening the hearts of those who wish for a fractured Europe. Mr Hunts comments sparked a backlash from supporters of a second referendum, who warned the Singapore model would mean turning the UK into a bargain basement for business. Best for Britain spokesman Paul Butters said: The Foreign Secretary wants to turn this country into a low-tax haven for business. Nothing would help the elite out more, while stealing from the public purse vital funds for key services and damaging workers rights. Jeremy Hunt is frustrating the will of the people when he says things like this. No one voted for big business to rule over us. story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Javid must beef up immigration security before a tragedyThe Home Secretary needs to break criminal gangs exploiting vulnerable people - their lives are at stakeShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  DEC NewsopinionHome Secretary Sajid Javid cut short his holiday to deal with the current refugee crisis "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter days of dithering, Sajid Javid has finally woken up to the fact that the refugee crisis is a “major incident”. These moves are necessary and to be welcomed. But he must also tackle the causes. Migration is a fact of le. There are lots of reasons people flee their homelands. Syria, for example, is a warzone and many Syrians have lost everything. In desperation, thousands have headed for Europe. And, because gangs are exploiting their panic and fear, one of the most dangerous parts of the journey is near the end. Organised criminals offer them a leline, but at an unbelievable cost: cut-price deals to allow migrants to put their children on boats.   This is not just a couple of conmen chancing their arms. These are cold, hard criminals who don’t caretheir “customers” live or die. One former coastguard officer says it is just a matter of time before there is a tragedy, and rescuers will soon be retrieving bodies rather than saving people. Mr Javid must act before that happens. That means beefing up our patrols and security. And it means smashing the evil networks exploiting vulnerable of people who are doing what we would all dowe lost shyeverything – trying to find a place of safety. Now, though, a hospital in Essex is trying to tackle the problem by offering nurses free use of a park-and-ride scheme for three months. title: armed gangs charging 5000 head
story: NewsArmed gangs charging £, a head to smuggle desperate migrant families to UKEXCLUSIVE: Families are being herded on to inflatables for the perilous -mile journey from Calais to the Kent coastShareCommentsByPatrick Hill:,  DEC NewsAhmad Lorpur has been living in a tent in Calais with his we and two children for four months "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailArmed gangs are smuggling shychildren into Britain on flimsy boats for pound,-a-head, a Sunday Mirror investigation reveals. The kids and their parents – who pay pound, each – are herded on to inflatables and small vessels for the perilous -mile sailing from Calais to the Kent coast. Iraqi Kurdish gangsters use secret social media pages and passwords to drum up business. Then, “like travel agents”, they target refugees in ramshackle camps offering the “special half-price deals” for children. One refugee told us: “You have to pay mafia here to get on a boat to England.” But once in the UK many are picked up by “Mr Bigs” and forced into slavery. Last night Save the Children called our findings “sickening” and echoed a warning by French police that children’s lives are being put at risk. Home Secretary Sajid Javid cut short his holiday to deal with the migrant crisis, which he called a “major incident”. And Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes yesterday held an emergency meeting with the Border Force, Immigration Enforcement and the National Crime Agency in Dover. Our probe came as the toll of migrants plucked from the Channel by British authorities since Christmas Day reached . Many are professionals, business owners or from middle-class backgrounds in Iran, Iraq and Afghanistan. They pay for the crossings after saving up, selling property or borrowing cash. Iranian Ahmad Lorpur, , has been living in a tent in Calais with his we and two children for four months while waiting for his chance to get to the UK. He told us: “You have to pay mafia to get on a boat. They are Iraqi-Kurds. “They call themselves ‘agents’, like travel agents. I have met one of them – a young Iraqi Kurd aged in his s. “He said he lives in England and that I needed to pay pound, each for me and my we to travel there. He said my children can go for half the price – pound,.” Standing with his kids Mariam, seven, and Benyamin, two, Ahmad added: “I have no money left now. It is all gone, butI had pound, I would pay it. “I paid ,to smugglers to get my family out of Iran and into Europe as we suffered persecution for being Christian. We managed to get here four months ago, but now we’re stuck. “It is no good for us here in Calais. My son is sick and we need help. “Everyone is waiting to get on boats to England. It is a big problem.”   An Iraqi-Kurdish refugee who is living at a camp  miles away, near Dunkirk, said desperate refugees contact smugglers through secret Facebook groups.The -year-old man, who lived in the north of England before being deported three years ago, asked not to be named for fear of reprisals. He said: “The names of the Facebook groups regularly change and it is not obvious what they are unless you know about them.“But after you’ve private messaged them, and they’re satisfied you’re not police, they send an agent to meet you in person. It’s still very cloak and dagger.“Once they’re completely happy, they negotiate a deal and give you a number to contact them on a messaging app like Telegram so it’s secure – as well as details of a bank account number for you or a family member to pay the money to. “I cannot risk giving you the details of the Facebook group becausethey found out I would be in a lot of danger. “They have knives and guns. I’m worried they could be watching now.” French officials say the number of detected illegal Channel crossings was  in  but has soared  per cent this year. But in Calais those determined to reach the UK are undeterred. While hundreds are putting their lives at risk on boats, others are paying pound, to stow away on lorries.  In the latest sea incidents, an inflatable containing four migrants was rescued off the Kent coast at around am on Friday.Six hours later another small boat was intercepted with eight people on board.That came after nine people, including three children, were intercepted on a beach in Sandgate, Kent, on Thursday.And more than  migrants were rescued from the Channel on Christmas Day.   Ingrid Parrot, of the French Maritime Police, said extra patrol vessels had been deployed to avert a tragedy. She added: “The figures are unprecedented and very disturbing. The risk is great.“There are  ships and  ferries crossing here every day. What’s more, the currents are strong and the winds almost permanent.” A senior French police source added: “Iraqi Kurds play a major part in the people smuggling rackets.“They are putting lives at risk while profiting from human misery. It is only a matter of time until lives are lost.” Two years ago, UK-based Iraqi Kurd gangster Twana Jamal,  – nicknamed The Godfather – was jailed for five years for a poundmillion-a-year cross-Channel people smuggling racket. And in September, two Albanians and five Brits from Kent were jailed for a total of  years after using small boats and a jet ski to smuggle people into the UK.

title: brit grandparents agonising choice bring
story: NewsBrit grandparents agonising choice as they bring ONE of murdered sons two children back to UKIan and Linda Simpson are finally bringing their six-year-old granddaughter back to the UK after her mum killed her dad - but they have had to leave her big brother behindShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsIan and Linda Simpson are pictured beaming beside their granddaughter, Alice, before boarding a train to Shanghai "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo British grandparents are finally bringing their murdered sons six-year-old daughter back to the UK - but have had to leave her big brother behind.Ian and Linda Simpson were seen beaming with joy beside their granddaughter, Alice, after signing an out-of-court agreement to bring her to live in Britain.They agreed to pay more than pound, to the family of their grandchildrens Chinese mum - who brutally stabbed their son, Michael, to death last year. Last night, they were preparing to fly back with little Alice.But the youngsters homecoming is filled with heartache - because Ian and Linda have been forced to leave their eight-year-old grandson, Jack, behind.   The desperate pair, who continue to fight for custody of the two siblings, had been faced with the agonising choice to bring just Alice back - or neither child. This is because Jacks Chinese grandparents, who live in the northwestern city of Nanzhang, are refusing to give the boy up, The Mail on Sunday reports. On Boxing Day, as his gran Hu De Xiu packed a bag up for his little sister, the youngster reportedly wept and pleaded with her: Don’t let Alice go.We are overjoyed to bring Alice home but it breaks our hearts to leave Jack behind, Ian, now married to a second we, told the newspaper yesterday.Linda cried and asked me, How can we wrench them apart    He added that, in the end, he and his ex-we had to choose between bringing Alice home or walking away without either of their grandchildren. We could have lost them both for ever, he said.Ian and Lindas son Michael was killed in March  when he was kned by his estranged we, Weiwei Fu, in a jealous rage at his Shanghai apartment. The Next executive, who had met and married Fu after moving to China before they split up, had planned a university education for Alice and Jack.He had taken the youngsters around the world and gave them a western view, retired business project consultant Ian said in an interview earlier this year.  He added at the time said: “We lost our son and feel we can’t lose the children as well. They’re too precious... We can give them the le Michael wanted for them. We’d make sure they stayed in touch with their Chinese relatives.” Ian and Linda, who have spent more than pound, in their bid to get custody of Alice and Jack, spent time with their grandson in Nanzhang last week.They played with him at a hotel restaurant, as Fus parents looked on. Devastatingly, the two childrens Chinese relatives have allegedly told them that their parents are working abroad and that Michael abandoned them. But in reality, the father was stabbed to death by their mother, who is now serving le in prison after being locked up for murder this summer.   Ian, of Hartest, Suffolk, said earlier this year: That’s the lie they’ve been given but they’ll find out eventually. It’s terrible. He added that the kids were living in a one-bedroom flat containing five people, including their grandparents and cousin, in a small town.The granddad and Linda had previously enjoyed a close relationship with Alice and Jack. But after their sons murder, they were allegedly refused contact. The pair launched a heartbreaking battle for custody, which saw Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt raise the case on a visit to Beijing in July. Supporters also raised thousands to help the family. Ian and Linda ended up paying pound, in cash to Fus relatives.  They have reached an agreement that there will be weekly phone calls between Alice and Jack, as well as annual visits, the Mail on Sunday reports. Now, as they prepare to bring their granddaughter back to the UK, they are determined to keep up their fight until Jack can join them too.They say Alice is already missing her big brother.She has been amazingly brave but there have been moments when she has been in tears asking for her brother, Ian said. The grandparents have been supported in their battle by the Foreign Office.

title: butlins asked family leave christmas
story: NewsButlins asked family to leave on Christmas Eve because their children were sickJess Underwood, of Penzance, Cornwall, claims her festive holiday with family at a Minehead resort turned into a nightmareShareCommentsByOlivier VergnaultTomas MalloyToby Meyjes:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsJess Underwood and her five children were asked to leave Butlins on Christmas Eve, she claims "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family claim they were kicked out of Butlins on Christmas Eve because their children were sick. Mum Jess Underwood had planned to spend the festive period at the Minehead resort with partner Stephen Grfiths, their five kids and another family of four. But she says their trip turned into a nightmare when two of their kids fell ill and then staff told them to leave. Jess said she and her family were forced to travel home to Penzance, in Cornwall, in the middle of the night and then had to find somewhere to eat on Christmas Day because they had no food in the house. Butlins policy section statesa guest has a contagious disease or illness they will be required to leave the resort, however a spokesman said the family will be offered a full refund.Jess told Somerset Live. When two of my children were sick in the night after we arrived I asked for clean sheets and some blankets because it was cold. They said someone would get back to me but no-one did.  I asked for some help again in the morning but again no-one called us back or gave us the clean sheets we needed. Two of my children and I had to sleep on the sofa because we could not change the sheets. They left us hanging all day the next day until .pm before they told us we had to leave immediately. They still charged us for a whole day before kicking us out even though theyve known since the night before that the children had been sick. No-one even asked after the children to see how they were. We were told we had one hour to get out then they had security guards escort us aswe had done something wrong. It was appaling. Butlins behaviour was utterly disgusting. Jess now vows her first trip to Butlins with children Summer, , Brooke, nine, Alyssa, six, Zailah, three, and Konnor, four, will be the last.  She added: We had taken a small Christmas tree and all the presents up there with us because we were supposed to spend Christmas at Butlins. We had to put everything back in the car in a rush and drive home to Penzance in the middle of the night and put everything back together at home in time for Christmas. We had to find somewhere to eat at the last minute because we had no food in the house as we were supposed to eat at Butlins and still paid the whole week for the catery. The children were so upset. They still remember it and talk about how we were kicked out of Butlins. What happened is outrageous. Jesss friend Roxanne and her family also left at the same time as they didnt want to be left on their own at the resort. The policy section of Butlins website confirms it is their right to evict anyone who falls sick on their premises. It reads: Should Butlins become aware, or have reasonable grounds for suspicion, that a guest has contracted a contagious disease or illness that has the potential to infect a large number of people quickly they and their party will be required to leave the resort. A Butlin’s spokesman told : “The first record we have of contact from the Underwood family was between . and am on December , when they informed us that some of their party were suffering sickness.“We advised the family that we would noty our housekeeping team. Our team made repeated attempts to call the family throughout the day to discuss next steps but were unable to make contact.“At approximately .pm on December , the family contacted us again to say three members of their party were now suffering with sickness.“Because we have to consider the welfare of all our guests and our team, where we believe any guests are suffering with an illness that could spread, we do regrettably ask them to leave.In this case, after the Underwoods contacted us again we spoke to them, assessed the situation and explained that we would need them to leave.We would only offer to quarantine guests in their room overnightthey informed us they had no means of travelling, and that wasn’t the case.“We certainly didn’t put any pressure on them to leave immediately, nor did we escort them off resort. It’s our understanding they eventually left early in the evening.“We refunded the Underwoods for the remainder of their break. Friends of the Underwoods, who were not unwell, also wanted to leave at the same time - we refunded them also. “Clearly this was not something we would wish for any guests at any time, but particularly on Christmas Eve.We hope the family members who were ill are now feeling better and we’re sorry that the delay between them contacting us in the morning and the decision to ask them to leave later that day exacerbated a very upsetting situation.With that in mind, we will be contacting the Underwoods so that we can express our apologies personally and arrange a full refund for them.”

title: dry january beckons here expert
story: NewsDry January : Expert tips for a painless, alcohol-free start to the new yearBrits drank a staggering  units of alcohol a week during the festive season and in January one in ten of us will aiming for a month offShareCommentsByRachel Spencer:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsInformation manager Alison Benson said she changed her le with Dry January"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe statics are quite shyfrightening andyou ever needed a reason to ease up on your booze intake, then now is the time – as Dry January is about to kick in. One in  adults – .million ofus – will have a month off the sauce, according to figures released by Alcohol Change UK. Many will have binged to excess over the festive period, when the average Brit drinks  units of alcohol a week. That’s nearly five times the  units recommended by the NHS. So taking part in Dry January will help you feel both healthier and wealthier. And banishing booze for four weeks can improve your relationship with alcohol in the long term. Dr Richard Piper, from Alcohol Change UK, explains: “Being alcohol-free for  days shows us that we don’t need alcohol to have fun, to relax, to socialise. “For the rest of the year we are better able to make decisions about our drinking and to avoid slipping into drinking more than we really want to. “Many of us know the risks of alcohol – seven forms of cancer, liver disease, mental health issues – but we are often unaware that drinking less has more immediate benefits too.” Dry January tips  Lauren Booker, author of Try Dry, The Official Guide to a Month off Booze, has these tips: . Have a clearout It’s a lot harder to stick to Dry Januaryyou still have bottles of wine and crates of beer in the house. You don’t need to pour it down the drain. Either lock it away in the shed so you’re not tempted or ask a friendyou can leave it at their house until the end of the month. . Treat yourself If you drink a couple of bottles of wine at home and have one night out a week, that’s pound a month on booze. Go on a spa weekend or do something you really love instead. Don’t use the cash for anything mundane. The Dry Jan app shows how much you save. . Find an alternative to your favourite tipple There are alcohol-free wines and beers so find one that tastes as much like your usual drink so you don’t feel you’re missing out. Andyour tipple is a GT try an alcohol-free gin which has all the taste. . Exercise more Exercise releases those feelgood shyendorphins, and you’ll find you’re less sluggish when you kick booze. It’s easier to exercise in the morning without a pounding headache. Andyou can’t hit the gym until later, you’ll have more energy so it won’t feel such a chore. . Buddy up If you can get a friend to join you on Dry January, it will be a lot easier as you can keep each other on trackyou are tempted to have a drink. Try to think of activities you can do together that don’t involve drinking – like going to see a film. If you do go out, decide what you’re going to say when someone asks why you’re not drinking. It will make it easier to stay strong and not think, “Oh, I’ll just have one...” . Get the Dry January app To sign up for Dry January, visit dryjanuary.org.uk or download the Try Dry: The Dry January app via the App Store or Google Play. It lets you track units, calories and money saved by not drinking.  Results from doing Dry January Research carried out by the University of Sussex into  Dry January participants found their drinking days on average dropped from . to . per week, the units on each drinking day fell by nearly  per cent, and episodes of drunkenness went from . a month to .. Four out of five felt more in control of their drinking,  per cent saved money,  per cent slept better and realised theydidn’t need drink to have fun,while  per cent had moreenergy. Over half,  per cent, noticed an improvement in their skin and  per cent lost weight. Being booze-free helped in their professional lives too, with  per cent having improved concentration. Alison Benson, , an information manager from Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs, did Dry January this year and hasn’t touched a tipple since.  She said: “I didn’t know when to stop. I found myself in unsafe shysituations and there would be occasions when I’d wake up and didn’t know how I got home – or I’d wake up in strange places. “I found Club Soda, a support group for women who want to stop drinking or moderate theirintake, went to a workshop last November and tried alcohol-free drinks. “On New Year’s Eve I had my last drink and since stopping I’ve felt less anxious, more clear-headed, my sleep has improved – and I still enjoy social situations. I always say I may go back to drinking, but I’m in no hurry to. Dry January changed my le.” Club Soda have a Mindful Drinking Festival in London on January  and . Find out more at joinclubsoda.

story: NewsInside the Royal Familys Christmas as Mike Tindall reveals how the Queen celebratedThe former England captain, , became an official member of the Royal Family in  after marrying Zara Phillips - and has now revealed some surprising royal festive traditionsShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mike-tindall-reveals-what-christmas-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRugby ace Mike Tindall has revealed some of the Royal Familys Christmas traditions in an interview offering a glimpse into Christmas at the palace. The former England captain, , became an official member of the Royal Family in , when he married Zara Phillips - the Queens eldest granddaughter. Speaking about his very royal Christmas, dad-of-two Tindall revealed how the family have a surprisingly alternative Christmas day - dining on a cold buffet as opposed to roast turkey and all the trimmings. He described how the most of the festivities are played out on Christmas Eve - including the opening of presents and a black tie party in the night. While most of the palace festivities at Sandringham take place on Christmas Eve, Tindall went on to reveal how the family - including The Queen - sit down to watch the monarchs annual Christmas Day speech, before some members of the family enjoy an episode of Downton Abbey. When it comes to present buying, Zara Phillips splashes out on up to  gts, which get handed out at a Christmas meal for extended family a few weeks before the big day.  Tindall added: My we is incredible at buying presents. There will probably be each year  presents because she takes presents for every single one of them. Two weeks ago, we had the family Christmas lunch which is all the extended family - ,  people and she buys everyone presents. My we is incredible at buying presents because she takes presents for every single one of them too. Comparing his Christmases up north with his parents, Tindall described how his traditions and festive attire are very dferent. story: NewsKate Middletons top assistant NOT about to leave despite kiss of death honourSpeculation circulated that Natasha Archer, , was to leave her role as the Duchess of Cambridges assistant after being named in the New Years Honours listShareCommentsByAmber HicksToby Meyjes:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsNatasha Archer wont be leaving Kensington Palace, a spokesperson has said "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRumours that Kate Middletons top aide is leaving after receiving a top honour have been dismissed as totally made up by Kensington Palace. Would you try the Greggs diet  Let us know in the comments below.

title: mum moved council 10 times
story: NewsMum moved by council  times in a YEAR tells of traumatic experienceGem Gardner, , from Nottingham, was even forced to stay the night in a McDonalds after a council deemed she had made herself intentionally homelessShareCommentsByJoseph Locker:,  DEC NewsGem Gardner was moved through  dferent hotels with her seven-year-old daughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distressed mum has revealed how she was moved by her local council TEN times within the space of a year.Gem Gardner claims she even stayed in McDonalds for the night as she had nowhere left to go. The -year-old, who has previously suffered from mental health problems, branded the experience of temporary accommodation as traumatic. She claimed Nottingham council even tried to get her to move to Derby - miles from her daughters school. Despite the numerous set-backs, her daughter, Success, had a % attendance record last year. Ms Gardner said: My relationship broke down in London so I had to come back to Nottingham as I had nothing left down there. I could not cope. I ended up with housing aid as I was in rent arrears and I became isolated and depressed.  Research had to be done to seeI had made myself intentionally homeless and I went through three dferent hotels in the six months it took for them to make a decision - which came back that I had despite my relationship breakdowns. I was all alone with my daughter then, and housing aid sent me to Loxley House and said they could help me. At one stage, Gem and her daughter were forced to stay in a hotel that didnt have electricity for three days. She said: When I complained, they threatened to kick me out. Some landlords can be horrible to deal with and take advantage of your situation. The travel costs to get my daughter to school were so expensive as we kept getting put so far away.Ms Gardner eventually got a solicitor and said it is unfortunate there is not enough concern put into where vulnerable women are getting placed. The council has now helped her get a privately rented house in Hyson Green, Nottingham She also has a job after graduating in applied social science and youth work at university, looking after a child on a one-to-one basis at a school.  She added: Im an educated woman. My situation is not who I am. It has opened my eyes to the reality of the system. It seems designed to make people fail. Its not surprising how people fall into prostitution and drugs. But when I was alone in London I thought, I have to do this for my daughter. I am hoping to get a house with my own name on it. My daughter wants to be a clothes designer and shes already wanting to help other people as well. She has written a few cards for homeless people this year. Were in a better position now, but there is always the worry about going back there. Councillor Linda Woodings, portfolio holder for housing and planning at Nottingham City Council, said: This has been a complex case and we’re glad that we’ve ultimately been able to support Ms Gardner back into permanent accommodation.  She was living in a privately-rented property with her child and came to us after her landlord evicted her for non-payment of rent. It took a lot of work to understand what had happened in Ms Gardner’s case and why she had been unable to keep up with the rent. This involved conversations with a number of partner agencies and she was temporarily housed while this took place. The use of bed-and-breakfasts and hotels is clearly not ideal, and the council remains on track to end their use for families by the end of the year. Properties are only used when they have been assessed by our safer housing team as meeting required standards. Where we’ve had concerns, the council has taken appropriate steps to help the owner improve things. Enforcement action is taken where necessary. Unfortunately, there are often restrictions in providing temporary accommodation at city-based hotels over the weekend. We have occasionally been required to move people ahead of the weekend, but always try to get them back into the same hotel so that children’s schooling isn’t disrupted.

title: mums attempt unblock toilet goes
story: NewsMums attempt to unblock toilet goes drastically wrong and sees home evacuatedDominique Heath, from Nailsea, Somerset, used two ordinary household chemicals to unblock her loo but ended up creating a poisonous gas cloudShareCommentsByTristan CorkAmber Hicks:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsDominique Heath has shared her story as a warning "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum had to evacuate her home and call emergency services after she created a poisonous gas cloud while attempting to unblock her toilet.Dominique Heath accidentally filled her home with deadly chlorine gas - which was used as a chemical weapon in wars - after using two ordinary household products hours apart. It was when the mum-of-threes throat and eyes started to feel asthey were burning and fumes filled the air that she realised something was very wrong and rang the fire brigade. They ordered her to evacuate her home immediately and cordoned off part of her street in Nailsea, Somerset, reports Bristol Live.  Fire fighters wore breathing apparatuses as they went into the house to ventilate it, and wash away the chemicals to make it safe. Dominique, who wants to warn others of the dangers how easy it is to cause a major chemical incident, had used two bottles of ‘One Shot’ toilet unblocker. Hours later she then poured bleach down the toilet, which she she thinks one of her young children blocked by putting too much toilet paper or a toy down there. “I put the kids to bed at pm, ran a bath, then looked in the toilet and it was still blocked so I thought ‘I’m not getting into the bath like this’, she said. I’ll put my three-litre tub of bleach down there, that should do it. But the bleach mixed with the toilet unblocker still in there causing a chemical reaction and released huge quantities of chlorine gas.  “I have never experienced fumes like it,” Dominique said. “My throat and eyes feel burned.” Dominique quickly shut the bathroom door and opened the windows around the house. However, the chlorine gas began to spread and she sought help from a neighbour and rang the fire brigade, who instantly realised how serious the situation was.The family didn’t get back to bed and sleep until am the following morning. Dominique posted the story on Facebook and shared her embarrassment at having to call out the firefighters, but said she wanted to share her story as a warning to others not to do the same. While the reaction from her friends was one of concern - and a degree of humour - the incident could have been very serious, and many commented that they also had no idea that mixing two normal household materials could effectively create a poisonous gas cloud. “It was really serious,” she said. “We are all ok, but it was the dumbest thing I have ever done - please don’t do this!”

title: parents tell hope tiny tots
story: NewsParents tell of hope for tiny tots born into the UKs leading neonatal unitSPECIAL REPORT: The NHS youngest and smallest patients arrive here and their fate is in the hands of a team of miracle workersShareCommentsByMartyn Halle:,  DEC NewsLittle baby boy Kayden was born  weeks early and is one of the tiny fighters at Southampton Children’s Hospital "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHis eyes are shut, he is connected to a raft of tubes and wires, but look at his tiny hand… seemingly raised in a gesture of hope. Baby Kayden lies peacefully in the incubator which has been home since his premature arrival into the world last month at just  weeks. Mum Melayne Pragnell is close by, reassured by the wonderful care Kayden is receiving in the state-of-the-art neonatal intensive care unit at Southampton Children’s Hospital. This is where the NHS’s youngest and smallest patients are fighting for their lives – their fate in the hands of medics who perform miracles on a daily basis. Often the tots’ skin is so thin you can see through it. They are clinging on to a le that has only just begun. Last week, the Sunday Mirror was invited to visit the unit as figures show , babies – seven per cent of all UK births – arrive prematurely each year. The atmosphere is calm, professional, yet warm and friendly too. Doctors, nurses and parents talk in hushed tones because noise could hinder recovery.  An illuminated ear on the wall goes from green to amber to red to showthere’s too much noise. It is a peaceful environment of darkened rooms. Incubators are covered by towels so that the still immature eyes of their little occupants aren’t startledthe lights are turned on. Care home worker Melayne, , wasn’t due to have her baby until mid-February. She and partner Kevin McDonough, , had been trying for children for  years and endured three cycles of IVF. But in mid-November Kayden was delivered weighing just g – .lbs – after Melayne developed a shycondition called placenta previa and suffered a potentially le-threatening bleed. Tiny Kayden made good progress, but suddenly declined  days ago after developing a potentially deadly E.coli tummy bug, then sepsis and meningitis. Doctors were on hand to respond quickly and are hopeful he will make a full recovery. Kevin said: “One minute we felt we were on the home straight – he was breathing by himself and things were looking up for Christmas. Then we were faced with a situation where he might be dead by Christmas.  “The doctors were very quick with their antibiotics. They put him to sleep and then put him on a ventilator.” Consultant and mum-of-four Victoria Puddy is one of the best in the field. Since she started  years ago, shyenormous strides have been made. Victoria said: “Now we are saving babies at  weeks when a decade ago we wouldn’t have considered rescuing a child so young. And we are not just saving them, some are leaving here unscathed.” Just five per cent of premature babies are born before  weeks. At  weeks, like Kayden,  per cent survive. Medics at Southampton are also caring for the daughter of a newly-appointed colleague. Abhijit Bhattacharaya, , had been working on the unit for just a week when his we Himakshi, also , went into labour at  weeks. Abhijit said: “I knew things were not good when my boss from neo-natal intensive care came into the theatre. “Our daughter Neysha was not breathing and they took her away and worked on her for  minutes before she started breathing. We are so, so grateful for their expertise.” As Abhijit spoke his we gently cradled Neysha’s hand. And just a few feet away lay another premature baby – tiny Sarah George, born at  weeks to parents Basil, , and Simi, . Doctors are using steroids and oxygen to help her lungs develop. The -cot unit is a centre of expertise when it comes to paediatric heart and neuro surgery. Consultants will even operate on the tots in their cotthey are too fragile to be moved. Like NHS staff nationwide, the team here is dedicated to its work. And that gives the likesof Kayden, Neysha and Sarah the very best ofchances.Find out how you can support the work of Southampton’s Children’s Hospital by visiting schcharity.org.uk

title: saira khan food bosses should
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Food bosses should cap calories to save us from ourselvesStealthy food industry tactics have led to obese sugar addicts - and its not just a case of iniduals having more self-discipleShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  DEC NewsopinionLosing weight is not just about personal discipline, it is also about those in the food industry "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor weeks I have used Christmas as an excuse to stuff my face and drink copious amounts of Prosecco. The only exercise I have managed to do is hoist my legs off the floor and on to the sofa.The only weights I have managed to lt is that of the remote control. And the crisp bowl. My Dancing on Ice training took an especially big hit on Christmas Day – I am definitely one of those people who consumed a staggering average of , calories on the th, according to research. And I don’t get where that figure comes from – how can some turkey, a bit of booze and a few chocolates and Christmas pud add up to that  And that’s the problem, isn’t it  Obesity – and the strain our unhealthy lestyles put on the NHS – is on the rise.But while most of us know the dference between healthy and junk food, when it comes to knowing the calories in food, we are literally stuffed. And it’s the hidden calories manufacturers sneak in that bug me the most. I consider myself a smart and informed person who is totally aware and fully responsible for the choices I make in my le.I understand that, in order for me to lose weight, I have to consume fewer calories than I burn, no matter what diet I’m on.And I get that the daily requirements for a healthy woman is to consume , calories per day. But I am not a nutritionist, I am a busy working mum – and quite frankly I just don’t have the time or the inclination to work out how many calories are in the food I eat.And evenI think I’m making a healthy choice, that’s not always necessarily true... and here come the hidden calories, sneaking their way on to my hips.  Losing weight is not just about personal discipline, it is also about those in the food industry – shysupermarkets, pubs, restaurants and even schools – informing the public in a very simple, clear manner exactly how many calories are in their products. So I welcome Public Health England’s recommendation that there should be a calorie cap on ready meals, supermarket sandwiches and restaurant items. Chief nutritionist Dr Alison Tedstone said: “These are early days in the calorie-reduction programme, but the food industry has a responsibility to act.” What this means is they will have to revamp recipes and rethink meal offerings.The recommendations include a cap of cals on ready meals,  on restaurant mains and , on pizzas. It’s about time too. These big manufacturers have to take responsibility. They have a moral obligation to stop adding unnecessary calories in the form of sugar and fat. Why do you need to add sugar to a slice of chicken   Stealthy ways to make our food more palatable has led to sugar addiction, which causes obesity.I’m not buying excuses from manufacturers that these caps are “unrealistic” – that screams they can’t be bothered and don’t want to spend money. In this fight against obesity, everyone has to do their bit – self-discipline can only go so far. Manufacturers have to start putting morals before profits and appreciate they they play an integral part in the nation’s health.

title: tragic final hours brit who
story: NewsTragic final hours of Brit who took her own le after boyfriend killed by Dominos driver"Beautul" Alice Robinson was found dead in Australia less than  hours after her beloved boyfriend Jason Francis died in hospitalShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsAlice Robinson and her boyfriend, Jason Francis, had moved to Australia from England "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe tragic final hours of a distraught British woman who took her own le after her boyfriends death have been revealed.Beautul Alice Robinson was found dead in non-suspicious circumstances in Perth, Australia, just two days before Christmas. Less than  hours earlier, her beloved partner, Jason Francis, had died in hospital after being hit by a Dominos delivery driver. The young couple, who had moved to the country from Shropshire under a year ago, had been sweethearts since their late teens.And Alice could not bear to live without Jason, her mum said. In the hours before her suspected suicide, the young woman had been at home while her boyfriend, , was out with friends.  Rugby player Jason reportedly enjoyed a Christmas drink with his pals during the catch up on December , before a cab was called.He is then said to have called Alice, telling her he would be back at their home in Stanley Street, Scarborough,“in a couple of minutes”.However, not long after, at around pm, sirens began wailing and Alice noticed flashing lights from emergency services vehicles. She went outside to see what was happening, Perth Now reports. It would later emerge Jason had been hit by a teenage Dominos delivery driver while reportedly lying on the road by his home.As he was being rushed to Royal Perth Hospital, his worried girlfriend was working her way through the crowd at the scene.Alice, a beautul soul, apparently collapsed in grief after police told her that her boyfriend was being transported to hospital.  She quickly set off to Royal Perth, with her devastated next-door neighbour, Colette, following behind her on the advice of officers. “They [the police] said I should go to the hospital to give some comfort to Alice, who they somehow knew didn’t have any support network here. I shot off as fast as I could, Colette said.But when she arrived at the hospital, Alice had vanished.Colette and her daughter, who was with her, began searching the hospital car park and then the streets for the young woman.“We knew she would have been in a terrible state, she added.However, they sadly could not find her.It was only later, less than  hours after Jason had succumbed to his injuries, that Alice was discovered dead in Mount Hawthorn.   Her heartbroken mother, Dawn, took to social media to pay tribute to a young woman who brought light to everyones le.She wrote: I am devastated to let everyone know that my beautul daughter was so distraught she could not bear to live without her beloved Jase and chose to take her own le. My husband and I now grieve for the loss of two wonderful people that brought light to everyones le. RIP my gorgeous girlie. Colette told The Sunday Times that Alice and Jason, who had been together for eight years, were very thoughtful neighbours. Jason was a former Market Drayton FC footballer before the pair moved to Australia, where they lived in the western city of Perth. He was on the carriageway in the beachside suburb of Scarborough when he was hit by a white VW Jetta, Western Australia Police said. The vehicle was being driven by an -year-old man.   It has been claimed that Jason was lying on the road by his house when he was struck, although this remains unconfirmed.The former fireman had joined Cottelsoe rugby club at the beginning of the year after moving to the area. Sam Diamond, club president, said he understood that Alice had gone outside to investigate after seeing flashing lights.Speaking earlier, he said: She was told by first responders that it was Jason they were working on. He added she had been left heartbroken by her partners death. We dont know what happened to her after this, Sam said. I know the police have launched an inquiry into it. She has gone missing after notying some of our friends of whats happenedand hasnt been found until the next morning. The couple, described as an integral part of the club, had made a big impression on the community in their short time there.   Sam added: They were two of the finest people you could meet. They well and truly ingrained themselves in our club.Both Jase on the field and Alice off the field. Alice, who worked for a digital marketing company and was also a talented pencil sketch artist, reportedly had an infectious laugh. Meanwhile, Jason has been described as the sort of person thats always got the time of day for everyone. More than pound, has now been raised to support the couples families and to help them pay for the repatriation of their bodies.A police spokesman earlier said: Police will investigate this matter and prepare a report for the coroner, which will include the full circumstances leading to the womans death.  Officers have also appealed for witnesses to the collision in Stanley Street at around pm on December . A Dominos Pizza spokeswoman previously told : Our thoughts are with the family of the victim involved and we remain focused on the health and wellbeing of the driver involved. We will provide all necessary support during this time including counselling and support services. Dominos is working closely with the police and their ongoing investigation. Whatever youre going through, the Samaritans are there to listen any time, free from any phone on  . They are there round the clock,  hours a day,  days a year.
